Euthynnus lineatus (little tunny or black skipjack)
Euthynnus yaito or Euthynnus affinis (kawakawa or little tuna)
Thunnus albacares or Neothunnus macropterus (yellowfin tuna)
Thunnus tonggol or Neothunnus rarus (tonggol tuna or longtailed tuna)
Thunnus obesus or Parathunnus mebachi (bigeye tuna)
Thunnus thynnus thynnus or Thunnus thynnus (Atlantic bluefin tuna)

Section.Text: The species of fish Sarda Chiliensis or Sarda Lineolata, after it has been canned, shall be designates as “Bonito” or “Bonito Tuna”.
In addition to the requirements of section 25, the labels on all cans of tuna shall indicate the colour of the fish flesh in accordance with the following colour classifications:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “White Meat Tuna” or “White Tuna” is canned tuna of the species Thunnus alalunga or Thunnus germo that has a diffuse luminous reflectance of not less than 33.7 per cent that of magnesium oxide;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Light Meat Tuna” or “Light Tuna” is canned tuna that has a diffuse luminous reflectance of not less than 22.6 per cent that of magnesium oxide when that reflectance is measured by a method prescribed by the President of the Agency; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Dark Meat Tuna” or “Dark Tuna” is canned tuna that does not meet the colour requirements of “Light Meat Tuna”.

Section.Text: Only canned fish that are produced from small clupeoid fish may be designated as “sardines”.

Subsection.Text: In this section “fish stick” means a uniform rectangular portion of breaded fish flesh that weighs not less than 25 g and not more than 50 g.
Fish sticks for sale in Canada shall be not less than 10 mm thick and shaped so that the length is not less than three times the greatest width and shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if cooked, contain a minimum of 60 per cent by weight of fish flesh; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if uncooked, contain a minimum of 67 per cent by weight of fish flesh.

Subsection.Text: Uniform rectangular portions of breaded fish flesh for sale in Canada that weigh more than 50 g shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if cooked, contain a minimum of 66 2/3 per cent by weight of fish flesh; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if uncooked, contain a minimum of 75 per cent by weight of fish flesh.

Subsection.Text: Fish sticks and other uniform rectangular portions of breaded fish flesh for sale in Canada that are prepared from minced fish shall have a descriptive term on the container of label thereof, in close proximity to the common name and in letters not less than half the height of the letters in the common name and in any case not less than 1.6 mm in height, declaring that the product is produced from minced fish.
Prepackaged fish and chips for sale in Canada shall contain fish that is batter-coated and when inspected by a method approved by the President of the Agency

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the batter-coated fish shall be not less than 45 per cent of the declared weight of the product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fish content of the batter-coated fish shall be not less than 25 per cent of the declared weight of the product.

Subsection.Text: French-fried potatoes in prepackaged fish and chips referred to in subsection (1) shall be of the grade required by the Processed Products Regulations for french-fried potatoes.

Section.Text: Breaded scallops for sale in Canada shall,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if cooked, contain a minimum of 60 per cent by weight of scallop meat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if uncooked, contain a minimum of 67.5 per cent by weight of scallop meat.

Section.Text: Unfrozen lobster meat and frozen lobster meat shall be free from the stomach, intestinal tract, gills, cartilage, shell particles, liver, roe and any other part that is not lobster flesh.

Subsection.Text: Each container of unfrozen lobster meat to which pickle or brine has been added, having the dimensions set out in an item of Column I of the table to this section, shall contain not less than the net weight set out in Column II of the table opposite that item.

Each container of frozen lobster meat to which pickle or brine has been added, having the dimensions set out in an item of Column I of the table to this section, shall contain not less than 95 per cent of the net weight set out in Column II of the table opposite that item.

Section.Text: Containers in which unfrozen lobster meat has been packed without the addition of pickle or brine shall be marked or labelled with the words “dry pack”.
Containers of frozen lobster meat shall be marked or labelled with the words “Frozen Lobster Meat”.
Where cooked lobster meat is processed for sale as unfrozen lobster meat, it shall, after being packed, be chilled immediately to, and maintained at, a temperature between 0°C and 2°C.
Where cooked lobster meat is processed for sale as frozen lobster meat, it shall be frozen immediately after it has been packed and shall be stored at a temperature of -26°C or lower.
Oysters in the shell shall be live, individual, undamaged oysters that are free from mussels, limpets, stones, mud and other extraneous material.
Each container of Atlantic oysters in the shell shall be legibly marked in such a manner that the area from which the oysters were harvested can be determined to the satisfaction of an inspector.
Atlantic oysters in the shell shall be graded and packed according to the following shapes:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Fancy Shape”, if the length of the oyster does not exceed one and one-half times its greatest width and it is not abnormally flat, thin-lipped or malformed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice Shape”, if the length of the oyster does not exceed one and three-quarters times its greatest width and it is not abnormally flat, thin-lipped or malformed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Standard Shape”, if the length of the oyster does not exceed twice its greatest width and it is not abnormally flat, thin-lipped or malformed; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “Commercial Shape”, if the oyster does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

Section.Text: Each container of “Fancy Shape” and “Choice Shape” Atlantic oysters in the shell shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: packed with oysters varying not more than 25 mm in length; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: legibly marked to show the minimum count of oysters contained therein.

Section.Text: No person shall mark or label any frozen gutted Pacific Salmon or any container thereof with a grade set out in section 66.2 unless the salmon conforms to the standard prescribed for the grade in that section.
Frozen gutted Pacific Salmon shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Grade A”, if it is whole, head on or head off, properly cut and cleaned and is free from all entrails, physical damage, bellyburn and signs of advances sexual maturity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Standard”, if it is whole, head on or head off, properly cut and cleaned and is reasonably free from entrails, physical damage, bellyburn and signs of advanced sexual maturity; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Utility”, if it is whole, head on or head off, eviscerated and not tainted, decomposed or unwholesome.

Section.Text: Frozen gutted Pacific Salmon shall be protected from oxidation and dehydration by a glaze of ice or a tightly wrapped membrane.
Where scallops are shucked on a fishing vessel, the scallop meat shall be washed and held in containers of a kind approved by the President of the Agency.
No person shall pack, sell, export or import any unfrozen scallop meat unless that meat is packed in a container of a kind approved by the President of the Agency.
Sea water or three per cent brine made with fresh water obtained from a source approved by the President of the Agency shall be used for washing scallop meat.
No person shall pack, sell, export or import

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any unfrozen scallop meat unless the meat is free from organoleptically detectable spoilage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any frozen or breaded scallop meat that does not meet the requirements of these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any unfrozen, frozen or breaded scallop meat unless the meat is free from pieces of roe, gut, shell particles, sand or other extraneous material.

Section.Text: Despite paragraph 70(c), scallops taken from an area approved by the President of the Agency may be packed, sold, exported or imported whole in the shell or with roe attached.

Subsection.Text: Shrimp cocktail shall be prepared from sound, cooked, peeled shrimp meat.

No person shall export or import any container of shrimp cocktail unless the weight of the shrimp, either expressed as a percentage of the net weight of edible contents in the container or as a declaration of the total weight of shrimp in the container, is declared on the label.
Unless otherwise permitted by the President of the Agency, containers of frozen Atlantic smelts shall be packed in accordance with the table to this subsection.
The length of a frozen Atlantic smelt shall be determined by measuring from the tip of the nose to the round of the tail of the smelt.

Section.Text: In addition to the requirements of section 26, a container of whitefish shall be correctly and legibly marked in English of French to show

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the lake of origin of the whitefish, including the name of the province; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the words “dressed whitefish” or “round whitefish” or “whitefish fillets”, as the case may be.

Section.Text: If graded for size, containers of whitefish shall be packed and marked in accordance with the Table to this section.
Containers in which whitefish is packed for export from Canada may be exempted by the President of the Agency from any or all of the provisions of sections 75 and 76.

Subsection.Text: No person shall cure fish for export as pickled, spiced or marinated fish unless the fish prior to curing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are free from organoleptically detectable spoilage, bruises and other discolorations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are clean, firm and properly prepared for the particular style of pack;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are free from all damaging feed or stomach contents; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), contain not less than 13 per cent fat.

Subsection.Text: Fish having a fat content of less than 13 per cent may be packed for export from Canada where a lower fat content is specified by a buyer in the importing country.

Section.Text: No person shall export pickled, spiced or marinated fish unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the containers in which they are packed do not leak;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fish are completely covered with the curing solution;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the fish are properly cured;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the fish contain a reasonable amount of fat;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the fish are free from organoleptically detectable spoilage, bruises and other discolorations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the fish are properly headed, where required, with a clean cut behind the collar bone; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the ingredients used in the curing mixtures are of a type acceptable to the President of the Agency.

Heading.TitleText: Types, Classes and Grades for Pickled Fish

Section.Text: Pickled fish shall be thoroughly cured and properly packed according to its type, class and grade as set forth in sections 82 to 96.
A class A pickled split herring, which is a pickled split herring that contains a reasonable amount of fat, shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Fat”, if it is a clean, properly split herring that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Fat tropic”, if it is a clean, properly split herring that is free from rust; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 4 Fat”, if it is a split herring that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) or (b).

Section.Text: A class B pickled split herring, which is a pickled split herring that contains no fat or only a small amount of fat, shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Bright”, if it is a clean, properly split herring that has the blood removed from the backbone, is free from rust and is reasonably white inside;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Tropic”, if it is a clean, properly split herring that is free from rust; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 4 Tropic”, if it a split herring that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) or (b).

Section.Text: Notwithstanding sections 82 and 83, a pickled split herring may be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 1”, if it is a clean firm, properly split herring that is bright in colour and that has the entrails removed and the blood removed from the backbone; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Seconds”, if it is a split herring that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a).

Section.Text: A pickled headless split herring shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Headless Split”, if it is a firm, white-bellied, properly split headless herring that is bright in colour and from which all entrails and the blood along the backbone have been removed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Substandard Headless Split”, if it is a split headless herring that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a).

Section.Text: A pickled dressed herring shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Dressed”, if it is a firm, headless herring that is bright in colour and from which the entrails and a strip of belly, extending from the neck to the anal fin, have been removed in such a manner that no bones protrude; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Substandard”, if it is a dressed, headless herring that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a).

Section.Text: A pickled herring fillet shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 1”, if it is a clean, firm, bright herring fillet that is free from rust and discoloration and from which the backbone and fins have been removed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 2”, if it is a herring fillet that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a).

Section.Text: A scotch cure pickled herring shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Full”, if it is a properly gutted, firm herring that is bright in colour and shows the roe or the milt at the throat; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Fillings”, if it is a properly gutted, firm herring that is bright in colour and does not show the roe or the milt at the throat.

Section.Text: A pickled split turbot shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 1”, if it is a white, properly split turbot that is clean on the back and face and free from blood along the backbone; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 2”, if it is a split turbot that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) and is not sour, “pink” or “red”, rusty or heavily sunburned.

Section.Text: A pickled split spring mackerel, which is a pickled split mackerel that has no fat or only a small amount of fat, shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Bright Spring”, if it is a clean, smooth-faced, properly split mackerel that has the blood removed from the backbone, is reasonably bright in colour, and is free from rust;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Spring”, if it is a clean, reasonably smooth-faced, properly split mackerel that is free from rust; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 4 Spring”, if it is a split mackerel that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) or (b).

Section.Text: A pickled split summer mackerel, which is a pickled split mackerel that contains a reasonable amount of fat, shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice”, if it is a clean, smooth-faced, properly split mackerel that has the blood removed from the backbone, is white in colour and is free from rust and blood stains;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Summer”, if it is a clean, well split mackerel that has the blood removed from the backbone, is of good colour and is free from rust and blood stains, whether or not it is slightly rough in appearance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Dark Summer”, if it is a clean, fairly well split mackerel that is of good colour and is free from rust, whether or not it is slightly rough in appearance; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 4 Summer”, if it is a split mackerel that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

Section.Text: A pickled split fall mackerel, which is a pickled split mackerel that contains a substantial amount of fat, shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice Fall”, if it is a clean, smooth-faced, properly split mackerel that has the blood removed from the backbone, is white in colour and is free from rust and blood stains;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Fall”, if it is a clean, well split mackerel that has the blood removed from the backbone, is of good colour and is free from rust and blood stains, whether or not it is slightly rough in appearance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Dark Fall”, if it is a clean, fairly well split mackerel that is of good colour and is free from rust, whether or not it is slightly rough in appearance; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “No. 4 Fall”, if it is a split mackerel that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

Section.Text: The types and grades for pickled mackerel fillets shall be those types and grades set out in sections 90 to 92 for pickled split mackerel except that, where reference is made to the removal of blood from the backbone, the reference does not apply.

Heading.TitleText: Pickled Headless or Pickled Trimmed Mackerel

Section.Text: The types and grades for pickled headless and pickled trimmed mackerel shall be those types and grades set out in sections 90 to 92 for pickled split mackerel.
A pickled split Arctic char shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice Red”, if it is a red fleshed, clean, firm, properly split Arctic char that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust, blood stains and other discolorations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice Pink”, if it is a pink fleshed, clean, firm, properly split Arctic char that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust, blood stains and other discolorations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Prime Mixed”, if it is a red or pink fleshed, clean, firm, fairly well split Arctic char that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust, whether or not it shows slight blood stains or is slightly rough in appearance; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “Commercial”, if it is a red, pink or white fleshed split Arctic char that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

Section.Text: A pickled split Atlantic salmon shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice”, if it is a red or pink fleshed, clean, firm, smooth-faced, properly split Atlantic salmon that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust, blood stains and other discolorations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Prime”, if it is a red or pink fleshed, clean, firm, fairly well split Atlantic salmon that has the blood removed from the backbone and is free from rust, whether or not it shows slight blood stains or is slightly rough in appearance; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Commercial”, if it is a red or pink or white fleshed split Atlantic salmon that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) or (b).

Subsection.Text: Containers of pickled fish shall be packed according to the length of the fish in accordance with Table I to this section or according to the count of the fish in accordance with Table II to this section.

The longest fish in any container marked “extra small”, “small” or “small medium” in accordance with Table II to this subsection shall not be more than 25 mm longer than the shortest fish in that container.

row.entry: (measured from tip of nose to round of tail)

Subsection.Text: The longest fish in any container marked “medium”, “large” or “extra large” in accordance with Table II to this section, shall not be more than 2 inches longer than the shortest fish in that container.

Section.Text: Bloaters and bloater fillets shall be properly cured and packed according to their grades as set out in sections 100 and 101.
A bloater shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice”, if it is a properly cured herring that has been smoked to a golden colour; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Standard”, if it is a properly cured herring, whether or not it has taken the smoke properly, is broken at the throat or belly or has other slight defects.

Section.Text: A bloater fillet shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Choice”, if it is a properly cured herring fillet that has been well smoked and shows considerable fat; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Standard”, if it is a properly cured herring fillet that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: All bloaters shall be packed by count in accordance with the weight of bloaters in the container.
The number of bloaters packed in a container holding 8.16 kg shall be indicated by marking or labelling the container with one of the following counts, whichever is appropriate:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: less than 61;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: more than 160.

Subsection.Text: Where the weight of bloaters in a container is greater or less than 8.16 kg, the count indicated by marking or labelling shall be proportionately greater or less, whichever is appropriate, than that required by subsection (2), as approved by the President of the Agency.
The longest fish in a container of bloaters shall not be more than 25 mm longer than the shortest fish in that container when measured from the tip of the nose to the round of the tail.

Section.Text: In this Part, salted fish means fish of the Gadidae family that has been preserved by salt and contains not less than 12% salt on a wet weight basis and a maximum moisture content of 65%.

Subsection.Text: No person shall place a product designation on a label affixed to a container of salted fish unless the designation is immediately adjacent to the common name of the product without any intervening printed, written or graphic matter and the designation is made in accordance with subsection (2).
Salted fish shall be designated as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “split fish”, if it is split and at least two-thirds of the anterior of the backbone has been removed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “split fish with entire backbone”, if it is split and no portion of the backbone has been removed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “fillet”, if it is a fillet as defined in section 2; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other designation that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is distinctive from those set out in paragraphs (a) to (c), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: No person shall place a class designation on a label affixed to a container of salted fish unless the designation is made in accordance with subsection (2).
Salted fish shall be designated as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “slack salted fish”, if, after the curing process is complete, it has a maximum salt content of 25% of the dry weight of the fish;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “light salted fish”, if, after the curing process is complete, it has a salt content of more than 25% but not more than 33% of the dry weight of the fish;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “dried heavy salted fish”, if, after the curing process is complete, it has a salt content of more than 33% of the dry weight of the fish and has a maximum moisture content of 54%; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: “green heavy salted fish”, if, after the curing process is complete, it has a salt content of more than 33% of the dry weight of the fish and has a moisture content of more than 54% but not more than 65%.

Section.Text: If more than one species of salted fish is packed in a container, the names of the species must be indicated on the label in the common name or in the list of ingredients in descending order of proportion.
Dried squid for export shall be dried to a moisture content not exceeding 22 per cent and shall be graded as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “Grade A”, if it is whole, properly split, clean, uniformly shaped and free from all entrails, physical damage, foreign matter, slime, dun, mold and pink, but excluding squid from which pink or dun has been removed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “Standard”, if it is whole, split, reasonably clean, free from foreign matter, slime, dun, and mold, whether or not it has traces of pink if the traces are not associated with spoilage and whether or not it is irregularly shaped with slight physical damage, but not if it is squid from which dun has been removed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “Utility”, if it is free from foreign matter or mold and has no detectable odour associated with spoilage, whether or not it shows pink discoloration or slight slime, whether or not it is skin-heated, is squid from which dun has been removed or is in bits and pieces.

Section.Text: The definitions in this section apply in this Schedule.

Definition.Text: cleaning means the removal of soil, food, fish residues, blood, waste water or any other dirt or debris from a processing area and processing equipment. (nettoyage)
disinfection means the reduction of the amount of micro-organisms to a level that will not cause serious contamination. (désinfection)
durable, in respect of construction material, means resistant to decay, breakdown or other physical damage. (durable)
impervious, in respect of any material, means an inert material such as concrete through which water or any other substance will not pass. (imperméable)
non-absorbent, in respect of any material, means a material that is highly resistant to the passage, absorption or incorporation of water or any other substance. (non absorbant)
non-corrodible means any metal or other material that does not readily rust, corrode, erode or otherwise decay. (résistant à la corrosion)
non-toxic means not injurious to health. (non toxique)

refrigeration facilities means freezers, cold storages, coolers, cool rooms and any other room inside an establishment where the ambient air temperature is reduced by mechanical means in order to preserve the quality and safety of fish (installations de réfrigération).
smooth means a fairly regular or even surface without projections, indentations or roughness and that can be easily cleaned and disinfected. (lisse)
sound means being in good repair or maintenance. (en bon état)
washable means being capable of being cleaned and disinfected with water, cleansers, disinfectants or liquids. (lavable)

Subsection.Text: The layout, design, construction and size of every establishment shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permit adequate cleaning and disinfection of all areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the accumulation of dirt, fish being in contact with toxic materials and floor surfaces, the shedding of foreign particles into fish and the formation of condensation or mould on surfaces;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: permit good production practices, including protection against contamination and cross-contamination by fish, equipment, water, air or personnel and any other sources of contamination, including insect and animal pests;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide, if necessary, suitable temperature conditions that permit sanitary processing and storage of fish; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the orderly and rapid movement of raw material and finished product into and out of the establishment.

Subsection.Text: Construction and packaging materials and non-food chemical products used in the construction and operation of establishments or in their equipment shall be suitable for the purpose for which they are to be used.

Saltfish, squid, stockfish and capelin may be dried outside an establishment if it is dried in a location away from traffic on grounds under the control of the operator of the establishment, on dryer flakes or other equipment that is raised at least 1 m above the ground or water and if the fish is handled to prevent the risk of contamination.

Section.Text: Floors shall be constructed of smooth, impervious, non-absorbent and non-toxic materials, be sloped for drainage and be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Subsection.Text: Drains shall be of a type and size sufficient to carry off any process effluent and water from processing and cleaning operations, be equipped with non-corrodible covers or grates and be constructed in a manner that prevents the entry of insect and animal pests, sewer gases or any other deleterious substance.
All drainage from an establishment shall be disposed of in a manner acceptable to the President or in accordance with local ordinances.

Section.Text: Wall surfaces shall be constructed of smooth, non-absorbent, durable and non-toxic materials that are light-coloured and thoroughly washable, in such a manner that all joints are sealed and floor and wall junctions are coved or rounded, and shall be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Ceilings shall be constructed of smooth, non-absorbent, durable and non-toxic materials that are light-coloured, washable, of a height acceptable to the President of the Agency and maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Heating units, water feed lines, piping, lighting, public address or radio systems or other overhead fixtures shall be designed, constructed, installed and finished to prevent the accumulation of dirt and to reduce condensation, the growth of moulds and the shedding of foreign particles into fish being processed beneath and, if the purpose of each is not readily evident, shall be labelled in such a manner that this purpose is readily discernable by an inspector.

Windows that are capable of being opened to the outside, and any other openings to the outside, shall be constructed so as to prevent the accumulation of dirt and be fitted with non-corrodible insect-proof and animal-proof screens or other similar devices.

Subsection.Text: Doors into and out of processing and support areas shall be constructed of smooth, non-absorbent and non-toxic materials that are washable, be properly fitted and hung and be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.
Doors in an establishment that is constructed after the coming into force of this Schedule

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be located so that persons may not enter directly into a processing area, with the exception of holding rooms, from outside the establishment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the doors are emergency exits from a processing area, shall be clearly marked “Emergency Use Only” or with other similar wording and be equipped with emergency door opening devices, panic bars or similar devices that prevent entry from the exterior of the establishment.

Subsection.Text: Fish processing equipment and ice handling or conveying equipment, including all surfaces, frames and legs shall be constructed of smooth, non-corrodible, non-absorbent and non-toxic materials that are washable, and shall be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.
Despite subsection (1), frames and legs of dryer flakes and dried squid storage bins may be constructed of wood if all surfaces in contact with fish meet the requirements of that subsection.
Despite subsection (1), bloater drying canes may be constructed of wood if they are clean and in a sound condition.

Despite subsection (1), boxes, carts or bins used to hold fresh whole or dressed fish intended for further processing may be made of planed lumber or waterproof plywood and be coated on the interior and exterior with material approved by the President of the Agency.
Despite subsection (1), ice screws or augers that are in contact with ice may be constructed of galvanized metal.

Section.Text: Cooler or cold storage racking systems on which pallets of fish are stored shall be constructed of metal or other material acceptable to the President of the Agency and shall be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Packaging and labelling materials shall be stored in dry and sanitary storage rooms that are intended for that purpose, that are constructed to provide protection from weather, contamination and the entry of insect and animal pests and that, if appropriate, are equipped with adequate temperature-control devices.

Subsection.Text: Ingredients and additives such as salt and vinegar used in the processing of fish shall be stored in sanitary storage rooms that are intended for that purpose, that are constructed to provide protection from weather, contamination and the entry of insect and animal pests and that, if appropriate, are equipped with adequate-temperature control devices.
Despite subsection (1), bulk storage of ingredients and additives in an enclosed area is permitted if the area meets the requirements of sections 3 to 8 of this Schedule.

Doors to areas referred to in subsection (2) shall be constructed of smooth, non-absorbent and non-toxic materials that are washable, properly fitted and hung, maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection, and so located that ingredients or additives may be unloaded and delivered or conveyed to a processing area in a sanitary manner.

Despite subsection (1), salt may be stored in bags outside of an establishment if the bags are sound, kept off of the ground and are covered with clean, waterproof coverings that protect the salt from contamination, weather and insect and animal pests.

Adequate supplies of water that meet one of the following requirements shall be provided in every establishment under a minimum operating pressure of 140 kPa for fish processing, establishment cleaning and disinfection, ice making, employee sanitation and personal hygiene and the operation of toilets:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the water has a coliform bacteria count, determined by a method acceptable to the President of the Agency, of not more than 2 per 100 millilitres; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the water is derived from a source approved by the President of the Agency.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of providing a safe and sanitary supply of water to an establishment, an inspector may require that water supply sources be chlorinated or otherwise treated.
Despite subsection (2), the President of the Agency may allow live shellfish to be held in an establishment in untreated water derived from a source approved by the President if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the median or the geometric mean of the faecal coliform most probable number in the water does not exceed 14 per 100 millilitres and not more than 10% of the water samples exceed a faecal coliform most probable number of 43 per 100 millilitres, as determined by a method acceptable to the President; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of the water poses no threat of cross-contamination in the establishment.

Subsection.Text: Steam

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: directly in contact with fish shall not contain any substance that is a hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be supplied in adequate quantities for retorting and any other purpose as specified in the establishment’s quality management program.

Subsection.Text: Ice making or ice storage facilities shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be operated in a manner that minimizes frost build-up;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if constructed after the coming into force of this Schedule, be built in accordance with sections 3 to 8 of this Schedule.

Subsection.Text: No ice making facility or ice storage facility constructed after the coming into force of this Schedule shall use wood on any surface that makes contact with ice.
Ice that is for use in an establishment shall be handled and transported in a manner that prevents its contamination.
No ice shall be used in an establishment unless it has been made from water that meets the requirements of this Schedule and is stored in a manner that prevents its contamination.

An establishment may use water that does not meet the requirements of subsections (1) to (3) for fire protection, boilers or auxiliary services if there is no connection between the other water systems providing water to the establishment and all feed lines and pipes are clearly labelled or coloured so that the purpose of each is readily discernable by an inspector.
Adequate supplies of hot water at a temperature of at least 43°C shall be provided throughout processing areas for cleaning and disinfection and at all handwash stations.
Hoses and other water delivery devices in ready-to-eat fish and shellfish process operations shall be equipped with backflow preventers or vacuum breakers.

Each operator of an establishment constructed after the coming into force of this Schedule shall keep and make available to an inspector, blueprints or other suitable drawings or sketches that show all water supply and water waste disposal systems, including sources of supply, intake locations, piping runs, treatment systems employed, location of water sampling valves for the taking of water samples before and after its treatment and the outfall or sewage hook-up locations.
Receptacles for the effective disposal of fish offal shall be provided, be clearly marked “For Offal Only” or with other similar wording or be colour coded, and be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with tight-fitting covers, as applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: constructed of non-absorbent and non-corrodible materials and kept in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if stored outside the establishment, placed on a concrete pad sloped to a drain.

Subsection.Text: Continuous offal handling systems that carry offal on conveyors or flumes to offal bins shall be constructed so that they pose no threat of contamination to the processing areas or to fish being processed and must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with tight-fitting covers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if located inside the processing areas, be constructed of non-absorbent and non-corrodible materials and kept in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if located outside the processing areas, be kept in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection and may be constructed of mild steel or other suitable non-absorbent metal; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if delivering offal to the interior of the offal bin, be located over or surrounded by a concrete pad of suitable size sloped to a drain.

Subsection.Text: Vessels, barges or conveyances may be used to store or transport offal to designated gurry grounds or fish meal plants if they are operated in a clean and sanitary manner.

Section.Text: Natural or artificial lighting shall be provided at intensities adequate to ensure the effective delivery to the processing operation being conducted, and the light fixtures shall have appropriate covers and be installed for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Natural and mechanical ventilation systems shall provide clean air, inhibit condensation and maintain conditions that are free from smoke, steam or foul odours, and any openings for the ventilation of the processing or support areas shall be fitted with non-corrodible insect-proof and animal-proof screens or other similar devices.

Subsection.Text: Refrigeration facilities shall be built in accordance with good engineering practices and with respect to freezing equipment shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contact freeze a 25 mm-thick block of unpackaged fillets to -18°C in two hours or less; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: air blast freeze fish at a rate that prevents deterioration of the fish, until the thickest section of the fish is at a temperature of -18°C .

Subsection.Text: Refrigeration facilities shall be operated in a manner that minimizes frost build-up.
Cold storages shall be equipped with automatic temperature recording devices capable of recording the temperature at least once every 24 hours.

In refrigeration facilities that are not equipped with automatic temperature recording devices, accurate thermometers must be installed and the temperature read and recorded at least once every 24 hours.
An operator of a registered establishment shall keep a record of each temperature recorded there for a period of three years.

Section.Text: Equipment that is used to perform product preservation processes shall meet the applicable requirements set out in the establishment’s quality management program.

Devices that are used to monitor the effectiveness of product preservation processes or the performance of equipment used in product preservation processes shall be calibrated and function in accordance with the applicable requirements set out in the establishment’s quality management program.

All facilities and equipment shall be maintained in a sound condition so as to minimize the risk of contamination to fish and facilitate cleaning and disinfection, and shall be installed in such a manner as to allow adequate cleaning of the surrounding area.
Flush toilets shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: present in adequate numbers for both sexes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conveniently located adjacent to processing areas;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designed so that toilet areas do not lead directly into processing areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with floor drains that will prevent any overflow of water or sewage from entering or contaminating a processing area, unless an inspector determines that there is no risk of serious contamination.

Subsection.Text: Washbasins shall be equipped with non-hand-operated taps.
Washbasins and other facilities or materials necessary for employee hygiene shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provided in adequate quantities, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conveniently located in or visible from processing areas.

Section.Text: Changing facilities for personnel and visitors shall be provided in every establishment that is constructed after this Schedule comes into force.

Utensils and cutting surfaces shall be constructed of non-corrodible, non-absorbent, smooth, impervious and washable material that is maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Subsection.Text: Conveyors in contact with fish shall be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection, be constructed of non-corrodible, non-absorbent, smooth, impervious, light-coloured and non-toxic materials or non-corrodible, non-absorbent, impervious and non-toxic wire mesh or chain link and, if necessary, be equipped with effective spray washers and scrapers.

Conveyors that are used for loading finished and packaged products into conveyances may be made of mild steel or other similar material and shall be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.

Section.Text: Pallets used as equipment in a processing area, such as foot stands, stands for vats and pan racks, shall be constructed of non-corrodible, non-absorbent, smooth, non-toxic and washable materials, and be maintained in a sound condition for ease of cleaning and disinfection.
Vessels with enclosed processing areas shall have, in addition to meeting other applicable requirements of this Schedule,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a clean and sanitary system for conveying fish from the reception area to the processing area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: storage areas for finished products that are large enough and designed so that they are easy to clean and, if a fish meal plant operates onboard, a separate hold must be designated for the storage of fish meal and other by-products;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: adequate equipment for pumping or disposing of processing effluent, cleanup water, waste or fish that are unfit for human consumption directly into the sea or in accordance with any laws regarding ocean dumping, into a watertight tank reserved for that purpose;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: adequate equipment for delivering pressurized clean and sanitary seawater for processing, the intake for which must be situated in a position where it is not possible for the water being taken in to become contaminated or affected by discharges into the sea of waste water, waste and engine coolant;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: walls, ceilings and non-slip floors that are easy to clean, in particular if there are pipes, chains or electrical conduits;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: hydraulic systems arranged or protected in such a way as to ensure that any leakage that could contaminate fish is minimized; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: marine type toilet facilities or other sanitary facilities acceptable to an inspector.

Section.Text: Every establishment shall implement and comply with its sanitation program.

Subsection.Text: Equipment and material used to clean and disinfect an establishment and processing equipment shall be provided in adequate quantities and be conveniently located in the establishment.

Any product used for the lubrication of fish processing equipment or machinery and any product used for cleaning and disinfection shall be clearly labelled as to its use, stored in an appropriate location and only used by a person trained to use or apply it in a manner that prevents contamination of fish or contact surfaces.

Employees shall wear protective clothing such as coveralls, aprons, sleeves, smocks, hand coverings, hair nets or beard nets that are in a clean and sound condition and suitable for the tasks employees are charged to perform.
No person shall enter a processing area unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: wears the protective clothing designated in the quality management program and appropriate to the tasks they will perform;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensures that their footwear is clean and sanitary and, if appropriate, uses a footdip to do so; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wears a hair net and, if appropriate, a beard net.

Subsection.Text: No person shall:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: handle or process fish unless they first wash their hands with single-service soap, wash or rinse their waterproof protective clothing, and disinfect their hands or hand coverings if either will come into direct contact with fish; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after leaving a production line, return to it unless they first wash their hands with single-service soap, wash or rinse their waterproof protective clothing, and disinfect their hands or hand coverings if either will come into direct contact with fish.

Subsection.Text: Immediately on leaving a processing area a person shall remove any protective clothing and store it in a manner that prevents contamination.

Section.Text: Pesticides or any other animal control products shall be applied in a manner that prevents the contamination of fish, packaging, labelling materials and ingredients.
Animals are not permitted inside an establishment.
Fish offal shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: collected in handling systems, receptacles or conveyances that are not used for the holding or transport of fish intended for processing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: disposed of or stored, before disposal, in a manner that will not attract insect and animal pests, allow the build-up of offensive odours or contaminate the area surrounding the establishment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: removed from the establishment or grounds under the control of the operator of the establishment as frequently as necessary to maintain the sanitation of the establishment, and as specified in the quality management program of the establishment.

Section.Text: Equipment and material provided to clean and disinfect protective clothing and footwear such as handdips and footdips shall be provided in adequate quantities and be conveniently located in processing areas.

Doors into and out of an establishment shall be kept closed and may be opened only when necessary to allow personnel, fish, equipment and other materials to enter or leave the establishment unless air curtains or other devices as specified in the establishment’s quality management program that prevent the entry of insect and animal pests are in operation.

No person who is a known carrier of a disease that is likely to be transmitted through food or who is afflicted with an infected wound, skin infection, sore, diarrhoea or any communicable disease, shall work in a registered establishment if there is a possibility of contaminating fish with pathogenic organisms.
A person engaged in the handling or processing of fish shall not wear any jewellery, fingernail polish or personal adornments that could contaminate or become incorporated into fish being processed.

Subsection.Text: No person shall smoke, spit, eat, chew gum or store food or other personal items not used in fish processing in processing areas.
Unnecessary material or equipment shall not be stored in a processing area.

Section.Text: Handwash and toilet facilities shall be maintained in good operating order and be properly equipped with single-service towels and toilet tissue, and all effluent and sewage shall be disposed of in accordance with local ordinances or, if none exist, in a manner satisfactory to an inspector.

Subsection.Text: The grounds under the control of an operator of an establishment in proximity to the establishment shall be kept clean, free from debris and unnecessary material and be maintained to minimize harbourages for insect and animal pests.
Areas where fish is loaded, unloaded or handled and other high traffic areas shall be paved with asphalt, covered with concrete or other impervious material and equipped with appropriate drains.

Section.Text: Forklifts and other devices used for moving fish and materials inside an establishment shall be clean and maintained in a sound condition.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall use wooden pallets in an establishment for any purpose other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to handle or transport boxed or otherwise containerized raw material in a holding room; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to transport ingredients, additives, packaging material, raw material, labels, semi-processed saltfish, or packaged, boxed or otherwise containerized finished products into or out of a processing area.

Subsection.Text: Wooden pallets may be used for the press piling of saltfish or the processing of salmon roe if a barrier of material suitable for food contact is placed between the wooden pallet and the fish.
Every pallet shall be clean and maintained in a sound condition.

Fish shall be kept iced or chilled and protected from contamination before processing in the establishment and, if the type of process operation conducted so requires, shall be washed before processing.
Cold storages shall maintain the temperature of fish at -18°C or colder.
Coolers shall maintain fish at a temperature from 4°C to -1°C.
Processed fish shall be stored in locations designated in the quality management program in order to preserve its quality and safety.
No odoriferous or toxic substance shall be stored in a processing area.

Section.Text: Frozen fish shall be handled and protected in an establishment to ensure that the temperature of the fish does not increase more than 5.5°C during the time the fish

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is removed from cold storage and returned to it unless the frozen fish is thawed for further processing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is placed on a conveyance equipped with cold-storage capability.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE III
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Requirements for Vessels Used for Fishing or Transporting Fish

Section.Text: Areas where fish and ice are stored shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have covers to protect the fish and ice from the sun and weather;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with drainage to effectively remove ice melt water and ensure that fish and ice do not come into contact with bilge water or other contamination; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where it is necessary to prevent physical damage to the fish, be divided into pens, which shall be shelved vertically at intervals of 90 cm or less.

Section.Text: Subject to item 3, fish and ice storage areas shall be of non-absorbent, non-corrodible materials, other than wood, and so constructed as to preclude physical damage to the fish and facilitate cleaning and any surfaces that contact fish shall be smooth and free from cracks and crevices.

In the case of vessels built prior to September 15, 1982 and vessels having no below deck storage areas, built-in fish and ice storage areas shall be so constructed as to preclude physical damage to the fish and may be of wood, if the surfaces are smooth, free from cracks and crevices and coated with a durable, light coloured paint or coating of a type approved by the President of the Agency.

Boxes for fish other than live shellfish shall be of smooth, non-absorbent, non-corrodible material, other than wood, free from cracks and crevices, and so constructed as to provide drainage and protect the fish from damage by crushing when the boxes are stacked.

Fresh fish storage areas shall be separated from engine compartments and other heated areas of a vessel by watertight, insulated bulkheads and wall surfaces, bulkheads and deckheads in frozen storage areas of a vessel shall be well insulated.

Fish handling equipment, such as chutes, conveyors, fish washers, tables and utensils, shall be of smooth, non-absorbent, non-corrodible material, other than wood, free from cracks and crevices and so constructed as to facilitate cleaning.
Forks, pumps, tools or other equipment and practices that pierce, tear, or otherwise damage or contaminate the edible portion of fish shall not be used.
Fish, while on board a vessel used for fishing or transporting fish, shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preserved by the use of finely divided ice sufficient to reduce and hold the temperature at 4°C or lower, and such ice shall be made from water from a source approved by a fish inspection laboratory; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preserved by such other methods as the President of the Agency may approve.

Section.Text: Where chilled water systems are installed on a vessel, such systems shall be of materials approved by the President of the Agency, be constructed to facilitate proper cleaning and be capable of holding fish at -1°C.

Freezing facilities on a vessel shall be capable of freezing the daily catch of fish at a rate equivalent to at least the freezing rate of a 25 mm thick block of fish when the temperature of the thermal centre is reduced from 0°C to -20°C in two hours or less.

Subsection.Text: Fish on board a vessel shall be frozen at a freezing rate not less than the rate prescribed by item 10.
In the case of a packaged fish product on board a vessel, the time required to reduce the thermal centre of the packaged product to -20°C shall not exceed 36 hours.

Except for brine frozen fish, the thermal centre of the fish on board a vessel shall be reduced to a temperature of -20°C or lower before the fish can be removed from the freezer to the cold storage area.
In the case of brine frozen fish on board a vessel, the thermal centre of the fish shall be reduced to -12°C before the fish can be removed from the freezer to the cold storage area.

Section.Text: After freezing, fish on board a vessel shall be glazed or packaged to protect it against dehydration and oxidation.
Storage areas in which frozen fish is held on board a vessel shall be maintained at a temperature of -26°C or lower.

At least once daily, fish receiving areas and all equipment, containers and utensils used in the handling of fish on board a vessel shall be thoroughly cleaned with water from a source approved by a fish inspection laboratory and disinfected.

Following the discharge of fish from a vessel, all equipment and utensils used in the handling of fish and the storage areas, chilled water system, fish containers, penboards and shelfboards shall be forthwith thoroughly cleaned with water from a source approved by a fish inspection laboratory and disinfected.
A storage record of the fish catch shall be kept on all fishing vessels and the identity of each day’s catch shall be maintained.
Handwashing and marine type toilet facilities shall be provided on vessels 13.7 m or more in overall length that have sleeping accommodation and shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE V
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Requirements for Conveyances and Equipment Used for Unloading, Handling, Holding and Transporting Fresh Fish

Section.Text: Forks, pumps, tools or other equipment and practices that pierce, tear or otherwise damage or contaminate the edible portion of fish shall not be used.

Fish handling equipment, such as chutes, conveyors, fish washers, tables and utensils, shall be of smooth, non-absorbent, non-corrodible material, other than wood, free from cracks and crevices and so constructed as to facilitate cleaning.

Subsection.Text: Fish shall be transported in covered containers approved by the President of the Agency or enclosed vehicle bodies.
The contact surfaces of fish storage areas in vehicles and of containers used for transporting fish shall be smooth, free from cracks and crevices and made of non-corrodible material.
The containers and vehicle bodies used to hold or transport fish shall be filled to a level no higher than 90 cm of its depth.
The body of a vehicle used for transporting fish in bulk shall be divided at intervals of 1 m along its length.
Fish held prior to being transported shall be iced or chilled after unloading from a vessel and be protected from the sun and weather and from contamination.
Fish shall be iced or chilled while being transported.

Section.Text: Water used for unloading, washing or transporting fish shall be clean and obtained from a source approved by a fish inspection laboratory.
Offal and other refuse shall be disposed of in a manner satisfactory to an inspector.
Areas where fish is landed or handled and all surfaces that come into contact with fish during unloading, handling, holding and transportation shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition.
The Fish Inspection Regulations10 are repealed.
